'''Claus Adolf Moser, Baron Moser''', {{post-nominals|country=GBR|sep=,|KCB|CBE}} (24 November 1922 – 4 September 2015) was a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[statistician]] who made major contributions in both academia and the [[Civil Service]].<ref name="guardian">{{cite news| first1=Muriel | last1=Nissel | first2=Jeremy | last2=Isaacs | authorlink2=Jeremy Isaacs | url=http://www.theguardian.com/society/2015/sep/06/lord-moser | title=Lord Moser obituary: Director of the Central Statistical Office who became chairman of the Royal Opera House | newspaper=[[The Guardian]] | location=UK | date=6 September 2015 }}</ref><ref name="telegraph">{{cite news| url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/11847342/Lord-Moser-obituary.html | title=Lord Moser – obituary: Statistician, economist, academic and champion of the arts and sciences who believed that all should benefit from high culture | newspaper=[[Daily Telegraph]] | location=UK | date=6 September 2015 }}</ref>  He prided himself rather on being a non-mathematical statistician, and said that the thing that frightened him most in his life was when [[Maurice Kendall]] asked him to teach a course on [[analysis of variance]] at the [[London School of Economics|LSE]].<ref>Claus Moser and 
Julian Champkin, 'Lord Moser'. ''[[Significance (journal)|Significance]]'', [[John Wiley & Sons|Wiley]], 
2 March 2007, {{doi|10.1111/j.1740-9713.2007.00217.x}}</ref>

==Life==
Claus Adolf Moser was born in [[Berlin]] in 1922. His father was Dr Ernst (Ernest) Moser (1885–1957), owner of the Bank "Ernst Moser & Co." in Berlin (est.  1902, [[liquidated]] in 1937). His mother was Lotte (née Goldberg, 1897–1976), a talented amateur musician. In 1936 he moved to [[England]] with his parents and his brother Heinz Peter August. He went to [[Frensham Heights School]] and the [[London School of Economics]] (LSE). Despite being [[Jew]]ish, in 1940, he was [[internment|interned]] as an enemy alien in [[Huyton#Second World War|Huyton Camp]]. 

After four months, he was released and served in the [[Royal Air Force]], 1943–1946. He then returned to LSE as Assistant Lecturer, then Lecturer, in Statistics, 1946–1955; Reader in [[Social Statistics]], 1955–1961; Professor of Social Statistics, 1961–1970; Visiting Professor of Social Statistics, 1970–1975.

He was appointed a [[Commander of the Order of the British Empire]] (CBE) in the [[1965 New Year Honours]],<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=43529 |date=1 January 1965 |startpage=10 |supp=yes}}</ref> and in 1965, he applied for a job at the [[Central Statistical Office, UK|Central Statistical Office]] but was rejected, as a former enemy alien. However, this did not seem to be a problem when in 1967 [[Harold Wilson]] appointed him Director of the Central Statistical Office. He was made a [[Knight Commander of the Bath]] (KCB) in the [[1973 New Year Honours]].<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=45860 |date=1 January 1973 |startpage=3 |supp=yes}}</ref> He resigned as Director in 1978.

He held a very wide variety of other posts. These included:

* Member, Governing Body, [[Royal Academy of Music]], 1967–1979 
* Director, [[Central Statistical Office (United Kingdom)|Central Statistical Office]], 1968–1978 
* [[British Broadcasting Corporation|BBC]] Music Advisory Committee, 1971–1983
* Visiting Fellow, [[Nuffield College, Oxford]], 1972–1980 
* Chairman, [[Royal Opera House]], [[Covent Garden]], 1974–1987
* Director, [[N. M. Rothschild & Sons]], 1978–1990 (Vice-Chairman, 1978–1984)
* President, [[Royal Statistical Society]], 1978–1980
* Chairman, Economist Intelligence Unit, 1979–1983
* [[Warden of Wadham College]], Oxford, 1984–1993<ref>[http://www.wadham.ox.ac.uk/about-wadham/college-history/wardens-of-wadham.html Wardens of Wadham], [[Wadham College, Oxford]], UK.</ref>
* Chancellor, [[Keele University]], 1986–2002
* Trustee, [[London Philharmonic Orchestra]], 1988–2000
* President, [[British Association for the Advancement of Science]], 1989–1990
* [[Pro-Vice-Chancellor]], [[University of Oxford]], 1991–1993
* Chairman, [[British Museum]] Development Trust, 1993–2003, later Chairman Emeritus
* Chancellor, [[Open University of Israel]], 1994–2004

He was made a [[life peer]] with the title '''Baron Moser''', of [[Regent's Park]] in the [[London Borough of Camden]] on 23 June 2001.<ref>{{London Gazette |issue=56259 |date=29 June 2001 |startpage=7687}}</ref> Other honours included the Albert Medal of the [[Royal Society of Arts]], 1996, Commandeur de l'[[Ordre National du Mérite]] ([[France]]), 1976; Commander's Cross, [[Federal Cross of Merit|Order of Merit]] ([[Germany]]), 1985.

Moser died in [[Switzerland]] on 4 September 2015, following a [[stroke]].<ref name="roh">{{cite news| url=http://www.roh.org.uk/news/british-statistician-and-former-chairman-of-the-royal-opera-house-claus-moser-dies | title=British statistician and former Chairman of the Royal Opera House Claus Moser dies: German-born academic, civil servant and life peer made a huge contribution to public life | first=Alasdair | last=Steven | date=5 September 2015 | publisher=[[Royal Opera House]] | location=UK }}</ref>

==The Claus Moser Research Centre==
In 1997, Claus Moser participated in a ceremony at [[Keele University]] to mark the start of construction of the Claus Moser Research Centre, a dedicated research facility for the Humanities and Social Sciences.<ref>[http://www.keele.ac.uk/news/week/archive/2007/0112/0112.htm The Week At Keele], [[Keele University]], UK, 12 January 2007.</ref> He returned to the university in June 2008 to participate in the official opening of the £3.5m building.<ref>[https://www.facebook.com/note.php?note_id=18207234226 Keele University Facebook bulletin], [[Facebook]].</ref>
